loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food for resale.

loans.name: Iye

texts.en:
This is 61 year-old Iye. She is married and has five children. None are in school.

In 1990, Iye established her textiles and ladies' shoes business. She began her business just to enable her to solve her own domestic problems and that is her only source of income. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 680,000 Leones (SLL) every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of 4,500,000 SLL. Iye requires a loan in order to buy wax cotton, bamako (tie-died cloth), and ladies shoes. The previous loan has enabled her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 140,000 SLL.

In the future, Iye still plans to travel to the holy land of Mecca and to buy more stock for her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy textiles and ladies shoes.

loans.name: Alekbar

texts.en:
Alekbar is 48 years old. He lives in Keshalo village with his 39-year-old wife and three children (20, 19 and 15 years old). Alekbar requested loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected every time, because of low income and the family's poor living conditions.

The only source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. They own a plot of land where eggplant, tomatoes and greens are grown. They also have a milk cow and 4 calves. The cows are milked every day to produce dairy products. All the products are sold at the local markets and among the villagers.

Alekbar requested loan from Credo to start a family business. Alekbar has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income. 

With his credit Alekbar will purchase stocks of groceries and open a grocery shop. He has a commercial space in a populous area, which will help his business to be successful. Family work in the shop themselves in order to decrease the expenses and increase the income. Alekbar is a very hard working man and he will work hard and long hours to make the business profitable in order to improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of groceries and open a grocery

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a solar panel for her house.

loans.name: Simona Del Camen

texts.es: Simona de 56 años de edad habita con su cónyuge y tiene 3 hijos en edades adultas;  desde hace 23 años, inició su experiencia de negocios  después de haber trabajado en una empresa, haciendo depender sus ingresos de su único medio al que decidió dedicarse: La venta de almuerzos, lácteos, mercancías variadas como cremas, útiles de aseo personal y hasta la confección de ropa. Ella poco a poco ha salido adelante con su negocio, porque visita a su clientela ofreciéndole a crédito y de contado, todos los artículos de su oferta; así desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde trabaja con esmero para lograr ser oportuna y vender cada vez mas. Sus compras las hace a empresas multinacionales, que le ofrecen guías especializadas de productos, con las cuales promociona los artículos. Su meta es crecer cada vez más, pero su capital de trabajo es insuficiente, para cumplir rápidamente el propósito que tiene frente a su negocio. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará telas e inusmos de confección, víveres en mayor volumen,  para obtener mejores precios en la producción de sus alimentos.  Con su experiencia de trabajo en el comercio, muy seguramente Simona hará realizada su sueño de prosperidad.
texts.en:
Simona, 56, lives with her spouse; she has three adult children.  She started her business 23 years ago after having gained experience working in a firm.  She decided to earn her income doing the only thing she knows how to do: to sell lunches, dairy products and varied merchandise like cream, school supplies, personal hygiene products and sewing clothes.  

She’s gradually made progress with her business because she visits her clientele to sell everything she offers for cash and on credit from 8 in the morning until 6 in the evening.  She works hard in order to be responsive and to sell more every day.  She makes her purchases at multinational firms that offer specialized catalogs of their products that she uses to promote her goods.   

Her goal is to grow more each time but her working capital is insufficient to rapidly reach the business goal she has set.  This is why she’s calling on a Kiva loan, he first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy fabric and sewing supplies and foodstuffs in larger amounts to get better prices in the ingredients for her dishes.  With her experience working in commerce, surely Simona will reach her dream of prosperity.

loans.use: to buy fabric, sewing supplies and foodstuffs in larger amounts.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey, 32, is a married man with three children in primary school. He lives in Kasambya-Kyotera community with his family. He was able to buy a plot of land in Kyotera with his earnings.

Godfrey is a teacher in a secondary school. Since 2009 he also has run a grocery shop, selling to neighbors in his community. He opened his small shop because he didn’t have enough money to start a bigger business and it’s easier to monitor it while teaching. Mwebe works twelve hours a day, seven days a week. One of his biggest challenges is his customers’ late credit payments.

Godfrey is applying for this 1,200,000 UGX loan through UGAFODE to buy additional stock for his shop. He hopes to expand it and then build rentals if his business does well enough.

Godfrey describes himself as a honest man. He would like to see lenders increase the size of their loans to clients.

loans.use: to buy additional stock for his shop.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a married man age 45 years. He has eight children and he lives in Kanagisa village with his family. Out of his eight children, four are still attending schools.
He is a farmer who deals specifically in banana and maize growing. He has been in agriculture business since 1998 and has managed to educate his children. He has also started a small retail shop for his oldest daughter. He started his business in order to earn money for educating his children and to develop his family.
He has acquired this loan in order to buy organic manure and pesticides for his new banana plantation and he knows that after adding manure and pesticides his plantation will be in position to yield more bananas hence increase his family income. This is his second loan; the previous loan was 1,200,000 UGX.
He sells his products to traders from Kampala. And his dream is to be the leading supplier of agricultural products in Kanagisa and to educate his children to higher levels of education.
However his biggest challenges in this business are high costs for buying pesticides and unpredictable weather conditions.
He describes himself as a hard-working man and asks lenders to be trustworthy and transparent to their customers.

loans.use: To buy organic fertilizer

loans.name: Fadzai

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 48-year-old Fadzai from Harare. She is married with three children, one attending school. She also cares for one additional dependent. Fadzai runs a retail business selling women's, men's and children's wear. The business has been in operation for 12 years. She says the main challenge is competition. Fadzai has requested a loan of $800 (USD) to buy more clothing for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to pay university fees for her son. In the future, Fadzai plans to open a big clothing shop in Karoi.

loans.use: to more clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rabbits

loans.name: Halil

texts.en:
Halil is forty-three years old. He is married and has two children between the ages of eleven and eight years old. Two of the children attend school currently. They all live in a village. Halil works as a lumberjack, cutting and selling wood. He provides woodcutting services and transport to those in his community to provide heat during the cold weather.

Halil started working in this business more than ten years ago. As a result of huge demands, he needs a loan to repair the tractor engine for transporting wood.

This loan will help to improve his business for the winter months. He will have a higher amount of demand and increase in the need for his services, therefore raising the income for his family. Halil hopes to generate more income and secure a better life and education for his children. Knowing that this is a Kiva loan he appreciate all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To repair the tractor engine

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Meet 42-year-old Zainab from Moriba town in Bo, Southern area, in Freetown. She is married with four children between the ages of 11 years and 25 years. Two of her children are currently attending school, and one is in university. 

In 1995, Zainab established her clothing business. She began her business because she needs to create income to educate her children. She works at the business 9 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is an improper business location.

Zainab requires a loan in order to purchase different kinds of clothing material for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to have a permanent business location and pay her children’s school fees. 

In the future, Zainab plans to educate her children up to university. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase different kinds of clothing material for resale.

loans.name: Claudia Patricia

texts.es: Gracias por apoyar a Claudia, quien con su credikiva compró yuca al por mayor, con ello atendió oprotunamente a su cleintela y sus ventas se incrmentaron. Sus utilidades crecierosn y está muy satisfecha tambien en lo personal pues su hija recibió grado como bachiller. Ella envia el siguiente mensaje a los finaciadores de Kiav :  " Gracias mil gracias, por apoyar tan noble causa,que el Dios de la Vida derrame muchas bendiciones sobre ustedes." En la actualidad está aplicando aun nuevo credikiva con el cual comprará bultos de yuca para continuar aumentando su prodcción de masa. Su esfuerzo constante, diciplina y ganas de trabajar harán de su credikiva una exitosa inversión.
texts.en:
Thank you for supporting Claudia who used her Kiva loan to buy manioc at wholesale and was thus able to tend to her customers in a timely fashion and her sales increased as a result.  Her profits grew and she’s also very satisfied on a personal level because her daughter graduated from high-school. 

She sends the following message to Kiva lenders: “A thousand thanks for supporting such a noble cause.  May the God of Life shower you with many blessings.”

She’s currently applying for a new Kiva loan she’ll use to buy bundles of manioc to increase production of dough.  Her Kiva loan will be a successful investment because of her constant effort, discipline and commitment to work.

loans.use: to buy bundles of manioc.

loans.name: Monica  Antonia

texts.es: Gracias por apoyar a Mónica, quien con su credikiva compró mercancía cosmética, perfumería papelería y ropa en general, con la cual surtió su negocio. Sus ventas se han incrementado y tiene mas clientes. En la actualidad está aplicando aun nuevo crédito con el cual comprará una vitrina de mayor tamaño,  productos como libretas, conjuntos femeninos . con los cuales la surtirá, así aumentará sus ventas y generar aun más ingresos. Mónica dice a sus financiadores: “Le doy gracias y que nos sigan apoyando a nosotros los pequeños empresarios, para sacar adelante nuestros negocios y hacerlos mas productivos. “
texts.en: Thanks for supporting Mónica, who with her Kiva loan bought merchandise such as cosmetics, perfumes, paper goods, and general clothing, with which she stocked her business. Her sales have increased and she has more customers. Right now she is applying for a new loan and with it, she will buy a larger display case and products such as notebooks and women's accessories so she can increase her sales and generate even more income. Mónica tells her financiers: “Thank you and I hope you keep supporting us small businesspeople to get our businesses ahead and make them more productive.“

loans.use: to buy a larger display case.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Agusta

texts.en:
Agusta sells diesel and gasoline outside her home every day and makes a good income doing so. She lives in a town near the main road, so many people come to buy gas from her.

Agusta opened her kiosk in 2009 with 400 USD in working capital. She would like to improve her business, so she is applying for a 1,000 USD loan through Tuba Rai Metin to buy more gas to sell.

loans.use: to buy more gas to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Seibatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 38-year-old Seibatu from Moriba town, Bo. She is married with three children between the ages of 4 years and 18 years. Her children are currently attending school. 

Seibatu runs a food stand; she sells rice, flour and cooking seasoning. She has been running this business for 15 years. She works at the business throughout the week and 10 hours per day. Seibatu says that at present, her business is doing well.

Seibatu has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking oil, rice and flour for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children’s school fees and increase her business. 

In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise more than ever. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, rice and flour for resale.

loans.name: Josen

texts.en:
Meet 37-year-old Josen. He is married and has two children, ages 15 and 16, who are both in high school. He runs a mobile money transfer shop in his hometown of Chingola.  When Josen is not at his shop, he can be found at one of the local schools where he serves as a teacher.

Josen describes his business as the safest way for people to send and receive money from one place to the other. He is requesting a Kiva loan so that he can improve the business by adding more working capital. He explains that the business of money transfers is highly dependent on how much cash and electronic funds one has in the business, and currently he does not have enough money. The lack of money in his business makes him lose out on business as he cannot serve some of his customers, especially the ones that want to transfer large amounts of money.

From the time Josen started, he has employed one person to help him with the day-to-day transactions at his shop. He is hopeful that, once he gets the Kiva loan, his business will improve and he will make more profit. The profit will help Josen to provide for his family and save for his children's college education.

loans.use: To increase his working capital float for his money transfer business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for community health work and taxi business.

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en:
Adelaide is a hardworking woman who runs a kiosk to help generate income for her family. She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of 600 USD.

Adelaide is applying for a 1,000 USD loan through Tuba Rai Metin to buy more stock for her shop such as flip-flops, cigarettes, cookies and soft drinks such as Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her shop.

loans.name: Maya

texts.en:
Maya is 35 years old. She is married and has three children, aged 18, 13 and 11.  

In 2000, she established her cow-raising business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 7 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy a young milk-giving cow.  

In the future, Maya plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction and as fuel for fires. Also, methane from the dung can be captured in methane storage tanks.  

The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young milk-giving cow.

loans.name: Kalpana

texts.en:
Kalpana is 34 years old. She is married and has one child who is six years old. 

In 2006, Kalpana established her business farming vegetables. She works four hours a day, seven days a week to support her family. She has already received and successfully repaid seven loans from Patan BPW, using her most recent loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for her business. 

In the future, Kalpana plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, borrowers are able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers for her business

loans.name: Ramila

texts.en:
Ramila is 35 years old. She is married and has 3 children, aged 18, 14 and 8.  

In 2003, she established her cow-raising business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 7 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy a young milk-giving cow. 

In the future, Ramila plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction and as fuel for fires. Also, methane from the dung can be captured in methane storage tanks.  

The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young milk-giving cow.

loans.name: Runya

texts.en:
Runya lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near the border of Tanzania. While beekeeping has not historically been a major activity in the region, the mangrove swamps closer to the coast and large passion fruit farms inland provide bees with robust sources of nectar. Though most farmers in the area are new to beekeeping, many are very enthusiastic about keeping bees. 

Runya is married, and has five children. Both he and his wife are farmers, and they are currently growing mangoes on their land. Runya is interested in starting beekeeping because it is a good source of income, and he is also looking forward to the benefits that the bees’ pollination will have on his mango yields. 

This is Runya’s first loan, and he plans to use the income generated by his beehives to improve his farm house. In the future, Runya would like to improve the scope and complexity of his beekeeping operations, eventually expanding it “to a commercial level.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though some of the towns along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives.

Peter is married, and has six children. Both he and his wife have been farming for 15 years, and are currently growing maize and mangoes on their land. Peter is excited to start working with Honey Care because their Hive Techs give efficient service on the beehives, and they provide free training as well. 

This is Peter’s first loan, and he plans to use the income generated from his beehives to pay his children’s school fees. In the future, Peter would like to increase his production of honey and start his own honey business.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Chardi

texts.en:
Chardi lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though some of the towns along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives.

Chardi is married, and has five children. He has been farming for 23 years, and is currently growing maize and beans. Chardi is excited to start beekeeping because it will enable him to have constant access to honey. 

This is Chardi’s first loan, and he plans to use the income generated from his beehives to make improvements to the farm. In the future, Chardi hopes to expand the number of farming projects he is involved in, in the hopes of providing a better life for his family.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and borders Tanzania to the south. Inconsistent rainfall makes farming difficult, and contributes to the area's high poverty rates. Despite the unreliable rainfall, bees in the region have two excellent sources of food: wild mangrove forests and local passion fruit plantations. Beekeeping is relatively new to the area, but many farmers are very interested in owning hives. 

Irene is married and has six children. Both she and her husband have been farming for 12 years, and are currently growing mangoes on their land. Irene is looking forward to working with Honey Care because their Hive Techs are trained to handle bees carefully and properly, and she is also excited to start earning money from the honey she sells. 

This is Irene’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated from her beehives to pay her children’s school fees. In the future, Irene hopes to continue to educate her children all the way through university.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near Tanzania. Inconsistent rains, especially recently, have made farming difficult, and the poverty rates in the county are above the Kenyan average. Beekeeping is somewhat new to Kwale, but the passion fruit farms and mangrove forests throughout the area provide excellent sources of nectar for bee colonies. Many farmers in the area have expressed excitement at the prospect of owning their own hives, and having a second source of income from their honey to help care for their families.  

Florence is married and has five children. She and her husband have been farming for 26 years, and are currently tending to an orange grove on their land. Florence is looking forward to working with Honey Care because they provide beekeeping training to all of their farmers. She has also heard that bees can have a positive impact on her crops through pollination, and this makes her even more eager to start beekeeping. 

This is Florence’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated from her beehives to pay her children’s school fees. In the future, she hopes to continue to educate her children, so they can provide for themselves and have a comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Dorca

texts.en:
Dorca is a member of the group called Fe y Esperanza, located in the city of Hato Mayor. This is her fifth loan, which she will use to improve her house. She has had her business for around three years. Since then she has paid back all her loans and expanded her business. After her last loan, which she invested in her business, she realized the need to improve her home.

This is the reason why she talked to other members of her group and they recommended her for a housing loan to improve her home by changing her old roof. She will buy zinc, wood, etc. to have a new roof. Dorca is the mother of 3 children and she lives together with her long term partner. She is running a business of selling groceries the school in her community.

Esperanza International runs a program for their good clients who are reliable in paying back their loans, who have fulfilled the commitment to grow their business and who have shown fidelity in their groups. This allows them to take out a loan to improve the structure of their house at the same time as running their business and attending their group meetings.

She thanks God, Esperanza International and all of you for this opportunity. In her name and that of her family, she thanks all of you for your support!

loans.use: To buy wood, zinc, etc.

loans.name: Farukh

texts.ru: Фарух молодой парень в возрасте 25 лет. Он  женат и  у него одна дочь которая родилась недавно. Фарух с детство занимается торговлей со своими родителями.  Они  занимаются  продажей  продуктов питания. Вот уже 2 года как Фарух работает самостоятельно и продает пищевые продукты. В обороте у него накопилось  немного денежных средств. Чтобы помочь  своим родителям Фарух самостоятельно занимается своим бизнесом . Он хочет в дальнейшем развивать свой бизнес  и для этого он обратился  в организацию   Арванд чтобы получит кредит .  На полученный кредит Фарух планирует закупить продукты питания и расширить свой ассортимент.  Заранее благодарит Арванд за поддержку.
texts.en: Farukh is a young, 25 year old man.  He is married and he has one daughter who was recently born.  Farukh has worked in retail since childhood with his parents.  They sell food items.  Farukh has been working independently for 2 years and sells groceries.  He has accumulated a small working capital.  In order to help his parents Farukh runs his business independently.  He would like to further grow his business and turned to Arvand for a loan. From loan proceeds Farukh plans to purchase grocery items and increase the assortment of goods in his store.  He thanks Arvand in advance for the help.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for his store

loans.name: Tej Kumari

texts.en:
Tej Kumari is 48 years old. She is married and has 5 children, aged 31, 29, 27, 25 and 23.  

In 2005, she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 7 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her business.  

In the future, Tej Kumari plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seeds and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast near the border of Tanzania. While beekeeping has not historically been a major activity in the region, the mangrove swamps closer to the coast and large passion fruit farms inland provide bees with robust sources of nectar. Though most farmers in the area are new to beekeeping, many are very enthusiastic about keeping bees. 

Ruth is married and has five children. Both she and her husband have been farming for 23 years and are currently tending to an orange grove on their land. Ruth is excited to start working with Honey Care because they offer good training, and she is looking forward to having her beehives produce honey as this will give her another source of income. 

This is Ruth’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated by her beehives to make improvements to her farmhouse. In the future, Ruth hopes to save up enough money to build a new house for herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter lives in a small town outside of Sagalato, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though some of the towns along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives.

Peter has three lovely children. He has been farming for 36 years and is currently growing maize and bixa, which is used as a source of both dye and fiber for making mats. He likes beekeeping because the bees will help pollinate his crops, and he is looking forward to working with Honey Care because they give detailed but simple beekeeping training. 

This is Peter’s first loan, and he plans to use the income generated by his beehives to make some improvements to his family home. In the future, Peter hopes to improve his beekeeping abilities, with the dream of pursuing beekeeping “at a commercial level.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Esha

texts.en:
Esha lives in a small town near Tsimba, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and borders Tanzania to the south. Inconsistent rainfall makes farming difficult, and contributes to the area's high poverty rates. Despite the unreliable rainfall, bees in the region have two excellent sources of food: wild mangrove forests and local passion fruit plantations. Beekeeping is relatively new to the area, but many farmers are very interested in owning hives. 

Esha is married and has one child. Her husband works in the transportation business, while she tends to the family farm. She has been farming for six years, and is currently growing mangoes on her land. She is interested in beekeeping because she is fascinated by bee physiology, and wants to learn as much as she can about bees and their behavior. 

This is Esha’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated from her hives to pay her child’s school fees. Esha’s hope for the future is to be able to continue to educate her child, all the way through university.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Gatarama

texts.en:
Gatarama lives close to Tsimba, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near Tanzania. Inconsistent rains, especially recently, have made farming difficult, and the poverty rates in the county are above the Kenyan average. Beekeeping is somewhat new to Kwale, but the passion fruit farms and mangrove forests throughout the area provide excellent sources of nectar for bee colonies. Many farmers in the area have expressed excitement at the prospect of owning their own hives and having a second source of income from the honey to help care for their families.  

Gatarama is married and has one child. His wife works in business training, while Gatarama tends to the family farm. He has been farming for six years, and is currently growing mangoes on their land. 

Gatarama is looking forward to working with Honey Care because their Hive Technicians give very efficient service, and he is also interested in the pollination benefits that bees will give his agricultural crops. 

This is Gatarama’s first loan, and he plans to use the income generated by his beehives to expand his beekeeping project. In the future, Gatarama hopes to increase the yields from his hives and become a “major honey producer.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi lives close to Tsimba, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near the border of Tanzania. While beekeeping has not historically been a major activity in the region, the mangrove swamps closer to the coast and large passion fruit farms inland provide bees with robust sources of nectar. Though most farmers in the area are new to beekeeping, many are very enthusiastic about keeping bees. 

Mwanaidi has three children. She has been farming for nine years and is currently growing mangoes. She is excited to work with Honey Care because she likes the way that they have simplified beekeeping training so that anyone can learn it. She is also happy to start beekeeping because it will provide her with a source of honey to treat ailments in her family and friends, like coughs and colds. 

This is Mwanaidi’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated by her beehives to build a family house. In the future, Mwanaidi hopes to be able to train the community on the proper uses, and medicinal properties, of honey.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Billiah

texts.en:
Billiah lives in a small town in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though some of the towns along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives.

Billiah is married and has six children. She has been farming for 32 years, and is currently growing cashew nuts on her land. She is looking forward to working with Honey Care because they provide good training, and she is happy to have another source of income in the form of honey sales. 

This is Billiah’s first loan, and she plans to use the income generated from her beehives to pay her children’s university fees.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Eilsa

texts.es: Gracias por el apoyo en la compra de una vitrina y mercancias con la que surtieron este negocio de variedades, ahora se ve con mas inventarios e impacta con esta nueva infraestructura a su clientela. En su negocio tiene 2 nuevos planes de celulares y está vendiendo minutos moviles. Se nota mayor amplitud mejor presentación  y la miscelanea tiene una mejor imagen comercial. Ella dice a sus finaciadores que se encuentra muy agradecida y que espera la sigan apoyando, para continuar creciendo y tener su negocio muy bien estructurado, por eso de antemano dice  "Muchas Gracias". En la actualidad comprará una nueva vitrina además de accesorios para bebe, con los que la piensa surtir, así tendrá nuevos productos en su oferta, de los que gustan a su clientela y que ultimanete han estado solicitando a esta micromepresa.
texts.en: Thanks to a previous loan which allowed her to buy a display case and goods for her business, Elisa now has more inventory and this new infrastructure is impacting her clientele. She offers 2 new cell phone plans and also sells cell phone time. The wider range of products and better display give her store a better image. She wants to let her lenders know that she is very grateful and hopes they will continue to help her, so that she can grow her business and have a smoothly running business. She says "thank you" in advance to future lenders. With the new loan, she will buy a new display case and baby accessories so she can have more supplies and more varied goods to offer customers, particularly goods that her customers want and have been requesting from this micro enterprise.

loans.use: to buy a new display case as well as baby accessories

loans.name: Artur

texts.en:
Artur is 47 years old. He lives with his wife and daughter in Vanadzor city. His elder daughter is married and lives separately from her parents. 

For a long time, Artur worked as a truck driver. For more than ten years, Artur has been engaged in the household goods trading business. He buys goods from Yerevan and Vanadzor wholesale markets, transports them to Lori region villages, and resells household goods to local village markets. 

Artur is very pleased with his job and the profit from his trading allows him to sustain his family and pay for his daughter’s education. Artur is the only bread winner in his family, so he works hard, day and night, in order to meet his small family needs. 

Artur asks from Kiva lenders a loan to repair his car and to buy household goods from Yerevan wholesale markets, for distributing and reselling in the Lori region.

loans.use: to repair his car and to buy household goods from Yerevan wholesale markets, for distributing.

loans.name: Leonidas

texts.en:
Leonidas is a member of the group called Fe y Esperanza Group 4, located in the city of Hato Mayor. This is her ninth loan, which she will use to improve her house. She has had her business for around four years. Since then she has paid back all her loans and expanded her business. After her last loan, which she invested in her business, she realized the need to improve her home.

Leonidas is a single woman, and she runs a beauty salon. This small business has given her enough income to provide for herself and to help her family. She is receiving a housing loan to improve her home by building an extra room, which she will build with a concrete block structure and zinc and wood for the roof.

Esperanza International runs a program for their good clients who are reliable in paying back their loans, who have fulfilled the commitment to grow their business and who have shown fidelity in their groups. This allows them to take out a loan to improve the structure of their house at the same time as running their business and attending their group meetings.

Leonidas thanks God, Esperanza International and all of you for this opportunity. In her name and that of her family, she thanks all of you for your support!

loans.use: To buy cement, concrete blocks and other supplies.

loans.name: Juana Alicia

texts.es:
Juana tiene 53 años de edad, esta acompañada y tiene 4 hijos. Desde hace 15 años trabaja cuidando ganado, actividad que aprendió de su mamá.  

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar tres vacas para engordarlas y posteriormente venderlas. Con la venta de las vacas, esperar comprar más y así dedicarse al comercio de ganado. Para generar ingresos que le sirvan a sus hijos para su estudio.
texts.en:
Juana is 53 years old. She has a partner and four children. She has been raising livestock for fifteen years, an activity that she learned from her mother. 

The loan she is requesting from Fundación Campo is to buy three cows to fatten and then sell. With the sale of the cows she hopes to buy more and in this way make a living off of livestock. Her earnings are used so that she can send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy three cows to fatten and then sell.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca, from the city of Puerto Plata, is one of the members taking a housing loan. This is her 5th loan, which she will use to improve her house. She has had her business for over four years, having started it with her own capital, selling fruit and vegetables. Her latest loan was invested in the business, which is now a small grocery store.

Esperanza Internacional runs a program for their good clients who are reliable in paying back their loans, who have fulfilled the commitment to grow their business, and who have shown fidelity in their groups. This allows them to take out a loan to improve the structure of their house at the same time as running their businesses and attending their group meetings.

Francisca wants to continue building her house, and with this loan she will finish building a bathroom. She is requesting this loan to buy cement, ceramics or tiles, a toilet and other bathroom's pieces). Also she is planning to buy paint. She thanks God, Esperanza Internacional and all of you for this opportunity. In her name and that of her family, thanks to all of you for your support!

loans.use: To buy bathroom parts (Toilet, Shower, tiles, etc.)

loans.name: Etelvina

texts.en:
$600 is offered to Etelvina to improve her business. She has a kiosk where many people come to buy every day. She will buy some additional supplies such as biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee and other items. She has been involving herself in business activities since 2012. She feels so comfortable to run her business because she can earn money every day.

Running a business has made Etelvina independent because she can be responsible for herself and also helping her family. She hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee and other items.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en: Filomena is applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She is running a business by selling gasoline. She is making a good income from selling gasoline and she wants to buy more stock with the loan. She is living in a town near the main road, so many people come to buy, and she is selling every day. She opened her kiosk in 2012 with her working capital of $120.

loans.use: to buy gasoline to resell.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 3,0000 through NWTF to buy more fruit to sell.

Fe has been in this business for 15 years. She earns more income from a general store and from selling frozen foods.

Fe has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Rosadel

texts.en:
Rosadel, of Gotocan Daku, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, is a 54-year-old woman. She is married, with six children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store selling groceries. She has done this for six years, earning 8,000 PHP monthly. It helps her family so much with their daily needs. 

To help increase their income, she recently borrowed 12,000 PHP from GDMPC micro-credit to purchase stock. Rosadel plans to use her income to finance their farm, so she will have multiple income sources and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store.

location.town: Gotocan Daku, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth lives in the Litein area of Kenya. She has three children and has been doing this work for five years.  Her primary income sources are;eggs, milk, crops and personal business.

She stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is digging.  Her biggest challenge is lack of enough financial resources. Animals on the farm have not been given names. 

Janeth was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "They offer good services."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and she replied, "'They are good for our lives."

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked, "How will this loan benefit her family' Janeth replied that it will improve their livelihood.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Janeth owns cows,poultry, but does not own pigs,a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net and running water but does not have electricity, solar power, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD..

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Lubov

texts.ru:
Любовь разведена, ей 62 года. Она торгует женской одеждой на центральном рынке. Лучше всего продаются легкие куртки, блузы,кофты и юбки. Основные конкурентные приемущества Любви - это умение торговать (большой опыт продаж в прошлом), приятная внешность, внимание к людям. Кредит нужен для закупки юбок, ветровок(курток)
Любовь надеежтся закупить товар, увеличить ассортимент и получить дополнительную прибыль.
texts.en:
Lubov is 62 years old and divorced. She sells women's clothing at the central market. Her most popular items are light jackets, blouses, sweaters and skirts. Lubov's main competitive advantages are her marketing skills (thanks to an extensive experience in sales), pleasant appearance, and attention to her customers.

Lubov needs this loan to purchase skirts and windbreaker jackets. She hopes to stock up on these goods, expand the assortment or her merchandise and earn additional profits.

loans.use: to purchase skirts, blouses and summer jackets

loans.name: Emanuel Group

texts.es: Este es el nuevo grupo “Emanuel” y está constituido por 05 socios entusiastas de comenzar a trabajar, siendo Sorayda la que preside al grupo. Sorayda es una mujer comerciante, pues toda su vida se ha dedicado al comercio por temporadas. Actualmente ofrece especierías, como ají, condimentos, entre otros. El dinero que percibe lo destina para algunos gastos de su hogar. Se siente feliz, pues gracias a su esfuerzo puede seguir apoyando a su esposo. Posteriormente tiene como meta aperturar una tienda, donde pueda ofrecer productos de primera necesidad. Solicitó el crédito para la compra de especierías y prendas de vestir como compas, pantalones y casacas para poder iniciar su nuevo negocio. Sorayda tiene 33 años de edad, casada con 04 hijos dependientes. El nuevo grupo  “Emanuel” agradece a las personas que hicieron posible éste crédito. Sorayda se encuentra sentada y viste cafarena color fucsia.
texts.en:
This is the new "Emanuel" group, and it is made up of 5 members who are enthusiastic about getting to work. Sorayda is the leader of the group. She is 33 years old, married, and has four dependent children. 

Sorayda is a businesswoman; she has worked in seasonal sales all her life. Currently, she sells spices, like peppers, seasonings, and others. The money that she makes goes toward some of her household costs. She feels happy, because thanks to her efforts, she is able to continue helping her husband. Her goal for the future is to open a shop where she can sell basic household items. 

Sorayda has requested this loan to purchase spices and garments like sweaters, pants, and jackets so she can start her new business. The new "Emanuel" group appreciates the people who have made this loan possible. 

Sorayda is shown seated and wearing a fucsia turtleneck sweater.

loans.use: to purchase spices, sweaters, pants, and jackets

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica lives in a small town in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and borders Tanzania to the south. Inconsistent rainfall makes farming difficult, and contributes to the area's high poverty rates. Despite the unreliable rainfall, bees in the region have two excellent sources of food, from wild mangrove forests and local passion fruit plantations. Beekeeping is relatively new to the area, but many farmers are very interested in owning hives. 

Monica is married and has four children. Both she and her husband have been farming for 29 years and are currently growing cashew nuts on their land. Monica is looking forward to working with Honey Care because their Hive Technicians provide good service and the beehives will be a welcome source of income for her family. 

This is Monica’s fist loan, and she plans to use the income generated by her beehives to pay her children’s school fees. In the future, Monica hopes to expand her apiary, eventually growing it to 20 beehives.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Mervat

texts.en:
Mervat is a 28-year-old married woman and the mother of one son and four daughters. She is a housewife and her husband is employed, earning a small salary that is barely enough to cover the family's needs and expenses. 

Mervat is requesting a 1,500 USD Youth loan from FATEN to help her pay the medical expenses of her son, who is suffering from a disease. This will improve Mervat's son's health and enable him to live in normal conditions with the family. Mervat and her son are shown in the picture.

loans.use: to pay for her son's medical expenses.

loans.name: Robby

texts.en:
Robby says that the previous loan helped him to increase his working capital. He was able to serve more customers coming to his shop to send and receive money. He says the added profits he made from his business helped him to open up one outlet in Lilanda compound. 

Today, Robby is taking out another loan because he would like to open a third shop in a town called Serenje. This loan will help him to purchase a new trading booth and have startup capital for his third shop. 
 
He is happy for his loans and thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a trading booth and use as startup capital for his new shop.

loans.name: Fransisca

texts.en:
Fransisca is 34 years old and she is now applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2009 with her own working capital of $600.  She earns a good income from her business.

She will use her loan to buy some stock to keep in her store such as body lotion, soft drinks, beer, noodles and other items to sell. She is a very hardworking woman and doing business has become her regular activity over the past 4 years. She wants to make her business bigger and improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: to buy body lotion, soft drinks, beer, noodles and other items to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman with seven children, four of whom are in school. She is 40 years old and a very hardworking entrepreneur. Josephine has a buy and sell livestock business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 5 years. 

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional livestock to sell. Josephine would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to sell.

loans.name: Jacquiline

texts.en:
Jacquiline is 32 years old and single. She works very hard to provide for her parents.

Jacquiline runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell. She has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Jacquiline would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, bread, chips, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en:
Presentacion is 63 years old and married with four children. Presentacion works very hard to provide for them.

Presentacion runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock like soft drinks, coffee, sugar, shampoo and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Presentacion has been in this business for 17 years and sells a variety of items. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock like soft drinks, coffee, sugar, shampoo and other groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
As a married parent of two, Nida works hard to support her family.

She has a general store in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling rice and dried coconut meat. Nida is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase more items to sell such as soap, shampoo, noodles, soft drinks, chips, bread, etc., for her general store.

Nida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 23 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell such as soap, shampoo, noodles, soft drinks, chips, bread, etc.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 51 years old, married, and has three children. 

Rosemarie is in the agricultural business, hog-raising in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Rosemarie has been in hog-raising for 21 years now and has borrowed 20 times in the past, from NWTF, to sustain the business. She would like to build and expand her business, to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Edgie May

texts.en:
Edgie May of Panta-on, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental is a married woman with two children. To make a living, she manages her owned farm land planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She earned 3,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from farming for five years. 

She is borrowing 8,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit to purchase fertilizer such as manure. In the future, she plans to use her generated revenue for their house improvement for a better shelter of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 62 years old and married with five children. With one child currently in school, Marilou works very hard to provide for them.

Marilou runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional items like canned goods, snack foods, soft drinks, noodles and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Marilou has been in this business for 30 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, snack foods, soft-drinks, noodles and other groceries.

Marilou would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like canned goods, snack foods, soft-drinks, noodles and other groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice lives in Sinkor, which is in Montserrado County. She is 46 years old and married with two children, ages 20 and 28. Both children are in school and live at home.

For the past 10 years, Beatrice has been selling dry meat in the community market. She started this business with the help of her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. She spends eight hours a day with her business.

Beatrice says, "I am business minded, and I like my business because it enables me to earn profits." She is requesting a loan to buy more dry bush meat to expand her sales. She intends to use the profits from her business to pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy more dry bush meat to expand her sales.

loans.name: La Fortaleza 2.1 Group

texts.en:
Adargisa, from the city of Hato Mayor, is one of the members taking a housing loan. This is her fifth loan, which she will use to improve her house. She has had her business for more than three years, having started it with her first loan. Her latest loan was invested in the business, in which she sells cosmetics and beauty products. 

Esperanza Internacional runs a program for their good clients who are reliable in paying back their loans, who have fulfilled the commitment to grow their business, and who have shown faithfulness in their groups. This allows them to take out a loan to improve the structure of their house at the same time as running their businesses and attending their group meetings.

Adargisa wants to start building her house with this loan. Her house was built out of deteriorated wood, and she will rebuild it with concrete blocks. Adargisa is requesting this loan to buy cement, concrete blocks, and other building materials. She wishes to have a safe and nice home, as well as to have an improved business. 

Roselia, the other member in this loan will also start building her house with a concrete block structure. She will buy the same building materials but in larger quantities. 

Adargisa and Roselia thank God, Esperanza Internacional, and all of you for this opportunity. On behalf of them and their families, thanks to all of you for your support!

loans.use: to buy concrete blocks, cement, and other building materials.

loans.name: Tigran

texts.en:
Young businessman Tigran was born in Kapan city, where he lives with his grandparents. More than five years ago, Tigran's parents moved to the Russian Federation for work abroad. 

Tigran is 24 years old. He graduated from State Armenian Engineering University but has never worked in that field. After serving in the military, Tigran had the chance to join to his parents in Russia, but as a very patriotic young person, he preferred to stay in his motherland and start his own business in his lovely city, Kapan. Last year Tigran rented a place in Kapan to run an internet and computer service business. His parents initially helped him buy some computers and furniture for his internet café. Now Tigran is very happy and appreciated by his business. Not every person has internet in his or her house in Kapan city, so Tigran has gathered a large number of customers in a short period of time. His main clients are students from Kapan. 

This is the first loan for Tigran with a financial company and he preferred to work with Nor Horizon and Kiva. He decided to expand the services in his internet café and asks from Kiva a loan of 2,900 USD to buy a new computer, new desks and a printer for his internet café. 

Tigran hopes for Kiva lenders' support in his newly created business.

loans.use: To buy a new computer, new desks and a printer for his internet café.

loans.name: Jjamer Samuel

texts.es: Gracias por apoyar a Jjamer, quien con su credikiva compró cascos para motos, chalecos, guantes, mangas, luces, calcomanías, llaveros etc. Desde que recibió su credikiva su negocio se ha incrementado, aumentó sus ventas y el surtido, y ha mejorado su calidad de vida e ingresos en su hogar. Jjamer envía agradecimientos por el apoyo recibido de los fondeadores de Kiva. Hoy está aplicando aun nuevo crédito, con le cual invertirá una vez mas, en la compra de modernos cascos, chalecos y calcomanías, que son los productos que mas rotan y requieren ajustarse a los requrimientos de la moda y la capacidad de compra que tienen los clientes, para hacer de su credikiva una inversión exitosa.
texts.en: Thank you for supporting Jjamer, who with his Kiva loan bought motorcycle helmets, vests, gloves, lights, stickers, keychains, etc. Since he received his Kiva loan, his business has grown, his sales have increased as well as his stock, and he has improved his quality of life and household income. Jjamer sends thanks for the support received from the Kiva funders. Today he is applying for a new loan which he will invest in buying modern helmets, vests, and stickers. These are the products that move the most and they require adjustments according to styles and the buying capacity of his customers, to make his Kiva loan a successful investment.

loans.use: to buy helmets, vests and stickers.

loans.name: María Félix

texts.es:
María tiene 57 años de edad, es soltera y tiene 8 hijos de los cuales tres viven con ella de 19, 13 y 7 años de edad respectivamente. Su familia esta conformada por tres hermanas juntas lucharon por salir adelante; ya que provienen de una familia muy humilde. Antes ella junto con su madre anduvieron alquilando casa en donde vivir, debido a que su padre las abandono cuando estaban muy pequeñas. Así que junto a su madre cultivaron maíz, frijoles y maicillo. También a la elaboración de petates de tule, por la pobreza en que Vivian ella aprendió a elaborar tamales de gallina, de cerdo y pan para salirlo a vender en la comunidad.  A los 15 años de edad, ella se acompaño y procreo 8 hijos, pero su compañero de vida la dejo con sus 8 hijos y ella ha tenido que trabajar mucho para alimentarlos. Sus hijos la apoyan mucho, con esfuerzo compro un terreno para construir su casa cerca del pueblo. Posee dos cerdos listos para ser destazados, desde hace 15 años instalo una pequeña tienda que le genera algunos ingresos. Y siempre cultiva maíz y fríjoles.  La mercadería para la tienda como los insumos agrícolas los adquiera en la ciudad que esta ha media hora de su casa en vehiculo particular ya que en donde vive no hay transporte publico. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar abono, fertilizantes, pago del alquiler de la tierra en donde cultivara maíz y fríjol. Con la inversión, comprara los insumos  a tiempo y en las cantidades correctas para obtener una buena cosecha que le permita asegurar la alimentación de su familia. Con los ingresos desea ahorrar para realizarle unos arreglos a su u casa y en el futuro comprar un vehiculo para salir a vender a las comunidades aledañas.
texts.en:
Maria, 57, is single and has 8 children, three of whom live with her and are aged 19, 13, and 7. Her family is made up of three sisters who work together to succeed as they come from a humble family. Previously, she rented a house with her mother for somewhere to live, as her father abandoned them when they were very young. 

This is how, alongside her mother, she began growing corn, beans and millet. She also made sleeping mats and, because of their poverty she learned to make chicken, pork and bread tamales to sell in their community. Aged 15 she started a relationship and had 8 children, but her partner left her and the children. She has had to work hard to feed them. Her children support her a lot and with hard work they have bought some land to build a house near to town. She owns pigs that are ready to be slaughtered and 15 years ago she set up a small shop, which gives them lots of income and she always grows corn and beans. She gets the merchandise for her shop, such as agricultural supplies in the city, which is half an hour drive from her home in a private car as there is no public transport where she lives.

The loan she is requesting, is to buy manure, fertilisers and to pay for the rent on the land where she grows corn and beans. With this investment she will buy seasonal supplies in the right quantities to acquire a good harvest so that she can be sure of feeding her family. With the income she wants to save in orders to make some repairs to their home and in future to buy a vehicle so she can sell to remote neighbourhoods.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertilisers and to pay rent on the land where she grows corn and beans.

loans.name: Wendy Elizabeth

texts.es:
Wendy tiene 33 años de edad, esta casada y tiene 4 hijos. Ella trabaja junto a una tía cocinando ya que posee un comedor. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar verduras, frutas, carnes, granos básicos, detergentes para instalar una tienda  y para elaborar los deliciosos platillos que vende en el comedor. De esta manera, podrá obtener mejores ingresos para su familia y brindarle a sus hijos educación ya que muchas veces se ve muy ajustada con los ingresos que recibe. Su deseo es poseer su propia casa.
texts.en:
Wendy, 33, is married and has 4 children.  She operates her business with an aunt who has a dining room they use.

Wendy is applying for a Fundacion Campo loan that she will use to buy the supplies she needs--vegetables, fruits, meat, detergent--to operate her business.  The investment will allow her to support her family and educate her children.  She says that she feels squeezed with the little income she has now and adds that she would like to buy a house of her own one day.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her food sales business.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell rice business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 17 years, and she earns more income from a general store.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to purchase more sacks of rice to sell. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Crispina

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Crispina works hard to support her family. She has a buy and sell banana business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs and chickens, operating a general store and from buying and selling native products. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 34 loans from NWTF.

Crispina is borrowing PHP 45,000 through NWTF to  purchase an additional stock of bananas to sell through her buy and sell banana business. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase an additional stock of bananas to sell.

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en: Ritchel is a 28-year-old woman of Cabungaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, married, and with two children. To make a living, she owns and manages a general store selling goods in their local community, earning 3,500 monthly. Recently, she borrowed 4,000 from GDMPC micro-credit to purchase additional stock for her store. In the future, she plans to buy agricultural land from her revenue.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her store.

loans.name: Cipriana

texts.en: Cipriana is taking a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She is running a rental for copy and printer that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as ink printers and photocopiers. She opened her rental copy and printer in 2013 with her own working capital of $1,000. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy ink printers and photocopiers

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan, of Tabid, Ozamiz City, is a married entrepreneur, with four children. 

For the last nine years, to make a living, he has operated a vulcanizing business. He earns PHP 7,000 per month from the business. As he planned to purchase materials needed for his vulcanizing business, he then borrowed PHP 9,000 from Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC). 

Allan hopes to improve his business, in terms of serving the community.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for his vulcanizing business.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol, from the city of Hato Mayor, is one of the members taking a housing loan. This is her 10th loan, which she will use to improve her house. She has had her business for more than five years, having started it with her first loan. Her latest loan was invested in the business, in which she sells natural medicine.

Esperanza Internacional runs a program for their good clients who are reliable in paying back their loans, who have fulfilled the commitment to grow their businesses, and who have shown faithfulness in their groups. This allows them to take out a loan to improve the structure of their house at the same time as running their businesses and attending their group meetings.

Marisol wants to finish building her house by painting it and installing gates on the balcony to protect access to her house. Here in the Dominican Republic, this is a way to be safe from thieves. Marisol is requesting this loan to pay to the hammerman for the gates. She wishes to have a safe and nice home. Thanks to God's will, she could save to build her house with her business profits and her husband's extra income. She thanks God, Esperanza Internacional, and all of you for this opportunity. On behalf of her and her family, thanks to all of you for your support!

loans.use: to buy paint and home protection (iron gates).

loans.name: Noorhan

texts.en:
Noorhan is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband, Fayez, appears in her Kiva profile photo, having the picture taken in his taxi.

Noorhan is a 54-year-old married woman and the mother of two sons and one daughter. Her two sons are employed with low salaries. For the past 14 years, Noorhan's husband has been driving a taxi, which has been a profitable project and the only source of income to the family. However, from time to time, he needs more support to cover some costs.

Noorhan is requesting a 3,000 USD loan from FATEN to help her husband cover the costs of licensing and insuring the taxi he drives. This will enable Noorhan's husband to work extra hours and to take additional requests legally, which will improve the family's income positively.

loans.use: to insure and license her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Valerya

texts.en:
Valerya, 49 years old and a widow, used to live with her family in Nagorno-Karabakh. But after the war conflict, her husband has died and she had to relocate to Lori region in Armenia. Now she lives in Arjut village, which is in Vanadzor region. Valerya’s daughters are married and live with their families separately from mother. 

Valerya has a higher education and a long time of experience as a biology teacher. The most important activity in Valerya’s life is teaching students. She is very pleased with her profession. But as the salary of teachers is too low in her region, Valerya has to teach and help students in her house. She organized two groups of students and prepares them for University exams. She has a good reputation as a biologist in her region and many students' parents trust Valerya with their children’s education. 

Valerya needs a loan to buy a computer and some books in order to improve the quality of biology training courses for her students.

loans.use: to buy a computer and some books in order to improve the quality of biology training courses for her students.

loans.name: Evilio

texts.es:
Evilio tiene 63 años de edad, esta casado y tiene 3 hijos. Desde la edad de los 5 años su padre le enseño a trabajar en la agricultura. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar semilla de yute, semilla de maíz, fertilizantes, pesticidas y herbicidas para sembrar 14,000 metros cuadrados de yute y 7,000 metros cuadrados de maíz. Con la cosecha de maíz asegurara la alimentación de la familia y la cosecha de yute le servirá para venderla de la cual obtiene buenas ganancias. Desea construir su propia casa para que sus hijos estén más cómodos.
texts.en:
Evilio, 63, is married and has 3 children.  He learned farming from his father, starting when he was only 5 years old.  

Evilio is applying for a Fundacion Campo loan that he will use to buy the supplies he needs--seeds for jute and maize, fertilizers, pesticides, etc--for his farming business.  He will plant 14,000 square meters of jute and 7,000 square meters of maize.  Evilio's maize crop is large enough to feed his family and he will sell the jute crop to generate a good cash income.  For the future, he wants to build a house of his own so that his children can live more comfortably.

loans.use: to buy the supplies he needs for his farming business.

loans.name: German

texts.en:
German is a married 52-year-old man of Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He earns 10,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from his own rice and banana plantation, which he has had for 20 years. He borrowed 15,000 PHP from GDMPC microcredit, with whom he's been a member since 2010, to pay for the weeding maintenance labor costs and buy manure fertilizer.

He plans to use revenue from the farm to repair their house to have a better shelter for the family.

loans.use: To pay for the weeding maintenance labor costs and buy manure fertilizer

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel is a 33-year-old married woman with three children recently living in Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamsi Occidental. She earns 8,000 PHP a month from her own farmland, planting rice and fruit trees. She has been in this business for 15 years. 

In order to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for her farm, she has borrowed  13,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) from GDMPC micro-credit, of which she's been a member since last year. In the near future, she plans to buy home entertainment appliances like television with the assets generated from their labor.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma is 60 years old, married, and has six children. 

Guillerma is in the agricultural business, pig-fattening in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional piglets, feed, and vitamins for her pigs.

Guillerma has been in this business for six years now and has borrowed two times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Guillerma would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets, feed, and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Areen

texts.en:
Areen is a 21-year-old married woman and the mother to one daughter. She is a housewife and her husband is a worker who earns a small salary, which is barely enough to cover the family's needs.

Areen is requesting a 1,000 USD Youth loan from FATEN to help her cover the cost of purchasing a new refrigerator and stove for her house. Taking this loan will offer to Areen and her family suitable home appliances so they can enjoy living in their house.

Areen, her husband, and daughter are shown in the picture.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and stove.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es:
Marlene, de 64 años de edad, está casada con Jorge y fruto de su matrimonio tiene 6 hijos que ya son mayores e independientes, vive en su casa propia junto a 5 hijos de los cuales brinda mayor atención a su última hija de 16 años, ya que los demás generan sus propios ingresos.El trabajo de Marlene, consiste en la venta de comida, instala sus mesas y sillas en la vereda de su hogar en donde ofrece a la venta gran variedad de platos regionales. Lleva realizando esta actividad desde hace 2 años y trabaja con la ayuda de sus hijos quienes le brindan el apoyo necesario para que todo siempre le vaya bien. De manera ocasional prepara diversos postres como queques, gelatinas , entre otros, los cuales los pone a la venta en un parque cercano a su vivienda.Le gusta mucho su trabajo pues continuamente está en contacto con las personas, se divierte, se relaja y sobre todo genera ingresos económicos para su hogar, de esta forma puede darle lo necesario a su hija menor, algunas veces lleva pedidos a domicilio y siempre tiene clientes que le solicitan sus deliciosas comidas, le esta yendo bien y espera establecer mas adelante un restaurante ya que tiene muchas expectativas en su negocio.En esta oportunidad solicitará S/. 3000, está agradecida y contenta al saber que sigue contando con el apoyo financiero que necesita para avanzar con el progreso de su negocio.
Con el monto solicitado comprará ingredientes e insumos como arroz, carnes, condimentos, aceite, y verduras para seguir con la preparación de sus deliciosos platillos, además comprará ollas y otros utensilios que necesitan renovación.
texts.en:
Marlene, who is 64 years old, is married to Jorge. From their marriage, they have six children who are already grown up and independent. She lives in her own house along with five of her children. She gives the majority of her attention to her youngest daughter, who is 16 years old; the rest generate their own income. 

Marlene's work consists of selling food. She sets up her tables and chairs on her house's sidewalk, where she offers a great variety of regional dishes for sale. She has been running this business for two years, and she works with the help of her children, who provide her with the support she needs for everything to go well. On occasion, she makes different desserts like cakes, gelatins, and others, which she sells in a park near her house. She likes her work very much because she is always in contact with people, she has fun, she relaxes, and above all, she makes an income for her household. That way, she is able to give her youngest daughter what she needs. Sometimes, she delivers orders to houses and she always has customers requesting her delicious meals. It is going well, and she hopes to establish a restaurant in the future, as she has high hopes for her business. 

At this time, she is requesting 3,000 nuevos soles [PEN]. She is grateful and happy to know that she continues to have the financial support she needs to make progress in her business. With the amount requested, she will buy ingredients and supplies like rice, meats, seasonings, oil, and vegetables to continue with the preparation of her delicious dishes; she will also purchase pots and other utensils that need to be replaced.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like rice, meats, seasonings, and oil, as well as pots and utensils.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet works hard to support her family. Juliet is single and has a shrimp-vending business in the Philippines.

Juliet requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to purchase feed for her business.

Juliet has been in this business for 16 years now. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her shrimp-vending business.

loans.name: Luvisminda

texts.en:
Luvisminda is 43 years old and married, with six children. With three children currently in school, Luvisminda works very hard to provide for them.
